title: 112_s1129
content: The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2011" amends the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to extend the terms of grazing permits and leases from 10 to 20 years. It also includes provisions for the renewal, transfer, and reissuance of grazing permits and leases. The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2011" defines key terms related to environmental analysis and the Secretary concerned. It mandates the renewal or reissuance of grazing permits or leases that expire, transfer, or are waived, under specific sections of the Act. The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2011" mandates the renewal or reissuance of grazing permits or leases under specific sections of the Act. Terms and conditions of expired permits continue until renewed, and permits may be cancelled, suspended, or modified. Renewal or transfer of permits is categorically excluded from environmental analysis requirements. The renewal, reissuance, or transfer of grazing permits or leases may be categorically excluded from environmental analysis if minor modifications are made and the current grazing management meets objectives in the land and resource management plan. The decision must also align with the policy of the Department of the Interior or Agriculture regarding extraordinary circumstances. The Secretary concerned has the discretion to prioritize and determine the timing for completing environmental analyses for grazing allotments, permits, or leases based on their environmental significance and available funding. This does not apply to renewals, reissuances, or transfers of grazing permits or leases that are categorically excluded from environmental analysis. SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY OF ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURE ACT TO GRAZING APPEALS. The Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 and the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 are amended to include provisions regarding the applicability of the Administrative Procedure Act to grazing permit appeals. The Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 and the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 are amended to include provisions for grazing permit appeals. Appeals must be filed within 30 days of the decision, and decisions are suspended until the appeal is resolved, unless determined otherwise by the Secretary concerned. The Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 and the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 are amended to include provisions for grazing permit appeals. An applicant granted grazing use in the preceding year may continue at the authorized active use level until the appeal is resolved in case of an emergency regarding resource deterioration.
